section_title: 3.1.1 Boolean Satisfiability as a Constraint Satisfaction Problem
section_purpose: This section introduces the Boolean satisfiability problem, defines key concepts like variables, literals, and conjunctive normal form, and explains how SAT is a special case of Constraint Satisfaction Problems (CSPs).
key_points: Boolean satisfiability (SAT) is a fundamental problem that asks whether a Boolean formula has a satisfying assignment with variables taking values from {0,1}.
Formulas are built from propositional variables and logical connectives (conjunction, disjunction, negation), with conjunctive normal form (CNF) being the most common representation.
A CNF formula is a conjunction of clauses, each clause a disjunction of literals, and any Boolean formula can be transformed into an equisatisfiable CNF formula.
An assignment satisfies a CNF formula if at least one literal in each clause evaluates to true under the assignment.
SAT is a special case of Constraint Satisfaction Problems (CSPs), where variables are Boolean and constraints are clauses, as referenced in Brailsford et al. [1999].

formulas: Conjunctive Normal Form (CNF) is defined as a conjunction of clauses, where each clause is a disjunction of literals; example given: (x1 ∨ ¬x2) ∧ (x2 ∨ x3).

dependencies: Basic knowledge of Boolean logic and propositional formulas
Reference to Brailsford et al. [1999] for Constraint Satisfaction Problem framework
reproducibility_notes: Understanding of SAT definitions, CNF representation, and assignment satisfaction criteria is essential for reproducing SAT solving methods.
